awd_titl_txt: Compositional and Temperature Controls on Structural Order, Dynamics, and Properties of Multicomponent Borosilicate Glasses
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION
Borosilicate glasses are widely used in technology, with applications ranging from heat- and chemical-resistant glassware and reaction vessels, to reinforcement fibers in ?fiber-glass?, to computer and television display screens. Many of these are central to multi-billion dollar U.S. industries, such as flat-panel TV?s and computer monitors. The atomic-scale structure of these materials controls their properties, which must be tailored to improve performance in their diverse uses. This project seeks to understand general principles of  how variations in the glass composition, and the way that it is heat-treated during manufacturing, change the glass structure in useful ways, to allow properties to be more easily predicted and engineered. The results of these studies should have more general interest as well, in other fields of science where glasses (and the liquids that form glass on cooling) are important, including geosciences and condensed-matter physics. Education is central to this project, since most of the research will be part of the training of Ph.D. and undergraduate students on their ways to careers in science and engineering.

TECHNICAL DETAILS
The most important experimental approach that will be used is solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, which provides quantitative details about the structure around many of the components common in technological glasses, including boron, aluminum, silicon, and oxygen. The P.I. and students in this program will synthesize several series of glasses with systematic variations in composition, and measure how glass structure changes. They will vary the thermal history of the glasses to look for clearly important, but poorly-known, effects of temperature. They will analyze results with thermodynamic modeling to allow prediction of critical properties. Much of the current development of improved and new types of glass materials comes from trial-and-error experimentation; it is thus an important goal to develop more fundamental understanding of structure-property relationships. Success with this goal could lead to new ways of thinking about designing glass compositions for new applications. Given major efforts in fundamental glass science in other countries, and the importance of the manufacturing of high-tech glasses in U.S. industry, it seems particularly urgent to progress in more basic understanding of these materials.

por.por_cntn:
Borosilicate glasses are widely used in technology, with applications ranging from heat- and chemical-resistant glassware and reaction vessels, to reinforcement fibers in “fiber-glass”, to computer, television and smart phone display screens and solar-cell substrates. Many of these materials are central to multi-billion dollar U.S. industries, based largely on research and inventions in American universities and U.S. glass industry research labs. The atomic-scale structures of these glasses control their properties, which must be tailored to improve performance in their diverse uses. This project has sought to understand general principles of  how variations in the glass composition, the way that it is heat-treated during manufacturing, and the pressures that can occur during bending and cracking, change the glass structure, to allow desired properties to be more easily predicted and engineered.

 

The research supported by this grant has lead to significant  progress in this fundamental understanding of effects of composition, temperature, and pressure on borosilicate glass structure. This has included some of the first detailed studies of the important changes in structure that take place on heat treatment, and how this changes as the glass composition is altered. We have found that temperature and compositional effects, often lumped together in typical studies of compositional series, need to be isolated from each other, and that this can be done by carefully designed experiments. We have determined some of the first detailed effects of high pressure on the structure of the types of complex glass compositions actually used in technology.  Our work has had important implications as well for related effects of these variables on the structure of glasses and molten materials that are of great interest in the Geosciences (magmas and volcanoes); technical developments that we have made in our primary research tool (nuclear magnetic resonance, NMR) have proven quite interesting in other fields of materials science and chemistry that use these methods.  This research has been published in major articles in the leading scientific journals in this field, and has been presented at several international scientific conferences.

 

Education and outreach have been central to the work funded by this grant. It helped support the research of three Ph.D. students, one post-doctoral student, an undergraduate and a high school student intern. All three of the Ph.D. students are women, who remain somewhat under-represented in the fields of high-tech materials research and solid-state chemistry (although this is now rapidly changing). This research has thus been a critical part of the training and scientific career development for all of the student participants. We have been active in outreach programs that serve local high school and middle school students and teachers as well.
